short_content.text: Climate Portfolio Offset procured by TheCoin

content.text: For this offset, we chose to do something different. Instead of going for an offset that targets one area of impact in emission reduction, we went for a combination of projects that collectively would reduce greenhouse emissions. The offset comprises energy efficiency projects, solar, wind, and biogas power, agricultural reforestation, and clean water access. So, why a combination of projects and not one? You may ask. Well! After internal deliberations, we gathered that there is no one silver bullet when dealing with climate change.

On the contrary, to effectively reduce greenhouse emissions, a combination of efforts is required. What better way to express this than to invest in an offset that combines multiple projects with a broader objective of reducing greenhouse gasses? You see our thinking. At the heart of climate change issues is a problem that is relatively easy to miss: energy consumption. Humans will always use energy. That is not even debatable. However, our energy use must be sustainable. How?

For one, we could start being more efficient in our energy use. By minimizing energy waste, our overall energy consumption reduces, effectively reducing our carbon footprint. I hope you now understand why energy efficiency is one of the projects under this offset. Secondly, we ought to move to more sustainable sources of energy. Here, renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, and biogas power are the way to go. Solar power will always exist and has minimal damage to the environment. On the other hand, wind power is not only renewable but accessible in most Western Countries, which are the largest emitters of greenhouse gasses. As for biogas, this energy source is renewable and uses waste, making it both efficient and effective in emission reduction.

Away from reducing emissions, we also need to look at the areas most impacted by climate change and mitigate some of the adverse effects. These areas include agricultural and water systems. Emissions have disrupted global weather patterns, directly impacting agriculture, which relies on the same. Similarly, due to climate change, our water systems have been adversely affected by unpredictable floods and an unhealthy water cycle. By mitigating the adverse effects of climate change in these areas, while simultaneously focusing on energy efficiency and renewable energy, we will have dealt a major blow to climate change, hence, our inclusion of all these projects in this offset.

title.text: African Biogas Carbon Programme Carbon Offset

short_content.text: African Biogas Carbon Programme Carbon Offset procured by TheCoin

content.text: This project is our most current carbon offset. We settled for it due to its combined climate change and social impacts. Implemented in Uganda, Kenya, and Tanzania, the project focuses on biogas, a renewable form of energy. Biogas is produced by the decomposition of animal and plant waste in an oxygen-starved environment and is used as an alternative to fuel and natural gas. The anaerobic digestion that occurs in oxygen-deficient environments breaks down the waste into methane and carbon dioxide. I know! You are probably wondering how biogas reduces climate change, yet it releases carbon dioxide and methane, which are both greenhouse gasses, into the atmosphere.

Well! Here’s your brief answer. First of all, it is true that both methane and carbon dioxide are greenhouse gasses and contribute to global warming. However, please note that plants, which are responsible for fixing carbon into the soil are the primary source of biogas. So, any emissions from the plant waste are essentially carbon neutral. That is why plants and trees are not considered sources of emissions despite releasing carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Their net carbon emission contribution is zero since they fix and release carbon into the atmosphere in equal measure. This point is the primary difference between biogas and fossil fuels. While biogas comes from plants that remove carbon dioxide and methane from the atmosphere, fossil fuels do not remove emissions at all. They only contribute.

You still don’t get it? Okay. Let’s try another angle. You see, biogas is a renewable source of energy. Like wind and solar power, biogas can be continuously generated from plant and animal waste. So long as plants and animals exist, they will always release waste, which can be digested into biogas. This is why they are considered a renewable source of energy. Renewable energy sources have a net positive effect on emission reduction compared to nonrenewable sources such as fossil fuels. I hope you now get the point.  If you don’t, you will get it by the time you are done reading this article.

Now, back to our offset, the countries hosting this project cut down trees and use them to make charcoal. Notice, they do not use plant waste. Instead, they cut down living trees, which would otherwise remove carbon from the atmosphere. Unlike in the case of biogas, which relies on natural plant or animal waste, effectively being carbon neutral, cutting down trees removes their carbon elimination potential. Worse off, instead of letting the cut down trees decompose into natural waste, they burn them into charcoal, a process that releases carbon monoxide into the atmosphere.

Even more problematic, when the charcoal is burned as a fuel, it releases more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. So, we have three problems here. First, trees that would otherwise remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere have been cut down, leading to more carbon in the environment. Secondly, the cut-down trees are converted to charcoal, a process that releases even more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Thirdly, charcoal as a source of fuel releases more greenhouse gasses. Compare that to using biogas, which relies on natural waste only, making it carbon neutral. Biogas is also renewable as plant wastes occur naturally. See why we invested in this offset. By allowing charcoal users in these countries to use biogas instead of charcoal, we have prevented huge volumes of carbon dioxide from entering the atmosphere.

short_content.text: Think investing is only for the wealthy?  Think again - here is a simple technique to generate serious money without saving a single penny!

content.text: When people hear of investing, a lot of us switch off.  Investing happens in our RRSP account or to people who have so much money they don't need it all.  It doesn't need to be like that.  We designed TheCoin for everyone.  We won't solve climate change if only the wealthy can afford the solution.

Here, we show how even someone with no savings can safely and efficiently boost their income with TheCoin.  This technique uses only the money you are spending.  You will offset a large part of your carbon footprint, but more importantly, you can generate hundreds of thousands of dollars over your lifetime.

All you need:
1) A money-back visa card.
2) An account with TheCoin.

This technique exploits the interest-free grace period most visa cards offer to create a balance with TheCoin.  When you purchase things with your Visa, you receive a short amount of time to pay back the purchase price without being charged interest.  Most cards have a billing cycle of 4 weeks.  The purchases are tallied up at the end of the billing cycle to calculate the amount due.  You then have three weeks to pay the amount owing in full.  If you do this, then no interest is charged on the card.

The combined billing cycle and due date mean you have up to 7 weeks where your purchases do not charge any interest.  At the same time, you've been earning the money needed to pay off the credit card.  This cash usually is sitting in your bank, not doing anything useful.  You could keep this money in TheCoin and watch it grow instead.

Seven weeks is not a long time, certainly not long enough to make any significant difference to your life.  The full power of this technique comes from the fact that you will repeat this process every four weeks for the rest of your life.  You don't invest for seven weeks - this small amount can remain invested for decades to come.  A small amount invested over a long time -can- change your life.  To demonstrate how, let's walk through this week by week, year by year.

Amy is 23 years old.  She's not a high earner or a big spender.  Amy has no savings and only earns enough each week to cover the $100 she spends on groceries and the odd night out.  She has just learned of TheCoin and decided it's time to make her money work for her.  She absolutely cannot afford to lose any money, so she creates her account with the maximum ShockAbsorber protection of 50%.  This level of protection will protect her from even once-in-a-lifetime recessions by topping up her account if the stock market drops.  After receiving her cash-back visa, she is ready to begin.

The first week, Amy puts her $100 spending on her visa card.  At the same time, she deposits her $100 earnings into TheCoin.  Her net balance is still $0 - she owes Visa $100 and has $100 in her account.  Amy spends another $100 the following week and deposits $100 in her coin account.  Her net balance is still $0; she now owes Visa $200 and has $200 with TheCoin.  Week 3 and 4 repeat the pattern, and at the end of week 4, Visa calculates her bill of $400, due in 3 weeks.  However, instead of immediately paying, Amy uses TheCoins auto-pay feature to pay on the last date possible.

Paying late achieves nothing in a regular bank account, but it makes a significant difference when your balance grows itself.  For Amy, even though her net balance continues to be $0, on week five her coin account grows to $500, and by the end of week seven it has grown to $700.    At the end of week seven, her visa bill is automatically paid, and she starts week 8 with $300 in her account.  At the end of week 8, Visa calculates her next bill of $400, with three weeks to pay it off.  Amy continues earning and spending until the due date.  On week 11, Amy again has $700 in the bank before paying the $400.  The cycle repeats.

Following this technique, Amys' balance with TheCoin stays between $300 on her billing date and $700 on her due date.  Her average balance is $500, and she is earning and spending $5200 each year.  A basic coin account will grow around 9% on an average year.  However, Amys' ShockAbsorber uses the first 6% of that profit to protect her from market crashes.  This means her actual gains will be a little lower; 9% - 6% is 3%, or around $15.  Her cash-back visa does quite a bit better, depositing $52 into her account at the end of her first year for a total extra savings of $67.

While it seems that TheCoin account isn't doing much to help, it gets more interesting in the following years.  Amy immediately puts her $52 into her coin account (her $15 is already there) and continues life as usual.  This additional $67 is savings, so she doesn't add it to her ShockAbsorber.  Even if the market drops, she isn't spending it anyway, so she can let it grow as fast as possible.  Now, her account gains $15 from the base $500 and another $6 from her savings for a total of $21.  With another $52 from her cash-back card, she now has an additional $140 in savings.

From these humble beginnings, Amy is on a path to genuine wealth.  After three years, her coin account grows an additional $15 + $13 for total savings of $220.  After four years, her account grows $15 + $20 for total savings of $306.  By the time Amy reaches 30 years old, she has an additional $616 in savings, and her coin account is growing faster than the cash-back card.

As she continues through life, Amys' account keeps growing.  Assuming she retires at 65, Amy will have an extra $30000, but it doesn't stop there.    Amys' account will continue to grow throughout retirement as she earns and spends to give lifetime earnings of well over $100K.
All of this, without saving a single penny.  Thanks, Visa!

There is another aspect to this story, and it is far more critical.  In Amys' first year with TheCoin, she offset 1.7 tonnes of CO2.  1.7 tonnes is more CO2 removed than comes from your car.  By 30, Amy removed 4.5 tonnes of CO2 from the atmosphere each year.  After 33 years, she is officially carbon-negative.  Over her lifespan, she removed far more carbon from the atmosphere than she put in.

Little choices can have enormous consequences.  Amy didn't do anything out of the ordinary.  She didn't save money or change her lifestyle.  Her only difference was a small choice made at a young age; She started using TheCoin as her spending account.  Apart from that one moment, everything else was the same.  However, that small moment resulted in a seismic shift in her life.  She reached levels of wealth she otherwise could never attain.  She did it with almost zero risk.  And, she did her part for the climate crisis, a struggle we all are part of.

1) Of course, this story has some very unrealistic scenarios.  For example, Amy would almost certainly spend some of her savings before retirement.  It's also doubtful she could go her whole life on such meagre earnings - $100 weekly is challenging to survive on today, but inflation will make it impossible in a few short years.  The article is intended to demonstrate the difference TheCoin would make assuming all other aspects of life are identical, rather than be a full simulation.

2) This article also uses a constant rate of 9% return.  In the real world, things are much messier, but that can be quite a good thing.  You can see what would happen to Amy if she tried this in the real world with our simulator - including her best & worst-case scenarios.  We encourage you to play around with the simulator to see how a scenario more similar to your own plays out

3) It's important to note that Amy has not paid any interest through this entire period.  The moment you slip up, Visa will gleefully slam you with interest rates so high they negate this whole technique.  We aren't in the business of helping Visa make money, so our app automates the process of paying the balance due at exactly the right time.

short_content.text: Turkey Wind Project Carbon Offset procured by TheCoin

content.text: For this offset, we went for a wind power project in Turkey. Our choice of this offset is informed by its tangible contribution to different facets of climate change, including transitioning from fossils to renewable energy sources and providing a sustainable source of emission avoidance. More importantly, the project is aligned to four Sustainable Development Goals that serve as concrete proof of its impact on the environment. In that regard, the project contributes to SDG 13 focused on climate action, SDG 7 on affordable and clean energy, SDG 8 on decent work and economic growth, and SDG 6 on clean water and sanitation. On SDG 13, the project stopped 131,241 tons of carbon dioxide, 36.3 tons of carbon monoxide, and 7.7 tons of Non-methane Volatile Organic Compounds (NVOC) from being released into the atmosphere. As for SDG 7 and 8, the project prevented the importation of 23,294 cubic meters of natural gas into Turkey and ensured social contribution by employing locals from the project area. Safety and Health training conducted in the project contributed to SDG 8. Lastly, on SDG 6, the project ensured that 4,912 cubic meters of wastewater discharge were avoided.

Sustainable Development Goals aside, you may wonder how wind power projects contribute to combating climate change. Well! Here’s a basic introduction. Wind energy reduces pressure on other nonrenewable energy sources such as fossil fuels. The reduced pressure eventually translates to reduced consumption of these harmful energy sources. Remember, nonrenewable energy sources are the most significant contributors to greenhouse emissions. Thus, by reducing their consumption, we will have effectively reduced their negative impact on climate change. This reduction allows for the replenishment of natural resources such as plants and animals that would otherwise be adversely affected by the heavy presence of greenhouse emissions in the atmosphere.

Moreover, wind energy projects stimulate economic growth in the wind energy sector, creating a multiplier effect throughout the economy centered around energy sources that are not harmful to the climate. The social impacts of wind projects such as creating local employment and promoting environmentally friendly practices are also worth noting. After all, the main objective of combating climate change is to improve the quality of human life by promoting sustainable co-existence between people and our environment.
